title: Intelligent Design
content: Let me preface this by saying that this is not an Evolution/Creation question.  I am simply asking if you think ID has the scientific merit to allow it to be taught in classrooms.[url=http://spatang.com/ck][img]http://spatang.com/ck/bannersm.jpg[/img][/url] [url=http://spatang.com/cosmo][img]http://spatang.com/cosmo/bannersm.jpg[/img][/url] [url=http://spatang.com/nukem][img]http://www.spatang.com/nukem/bannersm.jpg[/img][/url] [img]http://spatang.com/scrobblersig.php[/img]

title: iD software
content: Well, I can see no reason why it should not be taught. Too bad they didn't teach me about it.. Anyways, there's no 100% valid scientific thing they teach. The books change all the time and often the taught info is already outdated.Eat your veggies!

title: Re: iD software
content: Let me just clarify my question.  Should it be taught in a biology class?  I have no problem with it being taught in, for example, a philosophy class, but when it is taught under the guise of science, I take offense.[url=http://spatang.com/ck][img]http://spatang.com/ck/bannersm.jpg[/img][/url] [url=http://spatang.com/cosmo][img]http://spatang.com/cosmo/bannersm.jpg[/img][/url] [url=http://spatang.com/nukem][img]http://www.spatang.com/nukem/bannersm.jpg[/img][/url] [img]http://spatang.com/scrobblersig.php[/img]

content:

I am simply answering yes.

title: Re: Intelligent Design
content:

I like democracy but I'd hate it if it ruled in school too. It'd be like: "I don't want to study maths, why not study playing cards instead?"

*EDIT* I lied, I don't like democracy.

title: Re: iD software
content: That's a coincidence, there was a science show on a few days ago here where they discussed this very point.  The general consensus seemed that it's not a bad thing to be taught in itself, but the danger is when it uses up classroom time that could otherwise be spent teaching real science.

content:

title: Re: iD software
content:
Well;

ID doesn't really clash with science that much; it is usually merely a different was of looking at the same thing. One says 'wow, evolution has honed this creature to perfection' the other says 'Ah, look at Gods great work!' I see no problem with it being mentioned along with evolution, when E is being discussed. This really shouldn't take that long, just how many classes do you need to explain the nature of E and ID? The rest of bio is pretty much neutral, what does sugar metabolisim have to do with God?

However;

Those who think ID will create a world where nobody investigates things because 'its all Gods work' should be taken outside and soundly beaten. Those who promote ID at the expense of the real facts should be taken outside and kicked in the crotch. Both groups should then be forced to post in the same forum, like this one, for 10 hours a day.

A proud member of the signature stealing society

title: Re: iD software
content:
I just decided I will not participate in any of the phylosophical threads that popped up here recently anymore (barely did so far), as I never feel like it because so many things are said that I disagree with and feel like countering with my own arguments, although I know that is ultimately useless (at least for me, and I am egocentric), and after a while they become too large to even think about it, but this particular thread is still nice and small. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

I am against censorship, so I say intelligent design should at least be mentioned at school, as it is a theory, and even if it is not true, so are many theories discussed at school, sometimes because even replaced by better ones, they has such a large impact on history.
Should it be taught in biology classes?
No, I don't think it should, as it simply doesn't have enough scientific credit, whereas more mainstream theories do.
Also from what I understand intelligent design also explains the beginning, and biology is more about what happens after that.

The theory is basically a religious one, and religion and school should not be mixed.
There are an infinite amount of religious theories, so where would you stop teaching, and where would you even begin?Retodon8

title: Re: iD software
content:
I'm fine with it being included in a religion/theology/philosophy class, but it doesn't belong in science class, since it's not science. I'm not even worried about how it stacks up to other theories, but if it hasn't been arrived at through the scientific method, then it shouldn't be in science class (some necessary history excluded).________________

title: ID
content:
From a nuteral perspective:

ID, and Evolution are both Therories, and thus if they are therories, they are not fact. If you teach one theory, you must not teach it as fact. Thus, it is only fair that both theories be presented to the student.

-- NAJAWA --

title: Re: ID
content: Yes, yet it's taught as a fact around here. It's a theory that they consider true, but can't prove it (I think). [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] Eat your veggies!

title: Re: ID
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]From a nuteral perspective:[hr][/quote]

That's exactly the problem right there; that is your perspective, and I'm sure a lot of other people's, meaning not at all neutral.
If course my own, atheist perspective for instance isn't either, so in conclusion a truly neutral perspective simply does not exist.
The world is only what you see it as.
(People that complain about prepositions at the end of sentences should be kicked in the pants.)

From my perspective:
The ID theory is a religious one, religion being something about faith, therefore by definition not something about facts.
I'm not even talking about whether or not it's true, just whether or not it can be proven.
School shouldn't teach things which are based on faith, only things which are based on facts; religion and education should not mix.

Again, a lot of people and myself believe that, and a lot of people and you yourself believe otherwise, but again because of this whole "faith" thing there will never be consensus.
As long as we can all get along I personally don't even see this as a problem.

I thought about it recently, and I realise I simply don't do this faith thing.
I thought about it a bit longer, and I realise I do have hope, sometimes against better judgment even, but no faith.Retodon8
You live, you die, you are remembered, you are forgotten. [url=http://keen.retodon8.net/][img]http://retodon8.net/Graphics/Keen_Yorp.gif[/img][/url]

title: Re: ID
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]ID, and Evolution are both Therories, and thus if they are therories, they are not fact. If you teach one theory, you must not teach it as fact. Thus, it is only fair that both theories be presented to the student.[hr][/quote]
Sure but only one of them is a theory in the scientific sense of the word, and it's the only one that should be in science class. If you teach something in a science class then you're saying that it's a conclusion arrived at through a very specific process, the scientific method. If it's something you came up with in another way, then it should be in another class.________________

title: ID
content:
Okay, (This is similar to another example, but has a bit more detail) you take a picture of Keen's face, and you cut it into 5 peices. Let them drop. What is the chance of them landing inthe form of the origional picture, the same exact way... seemlessly. Now, take that same picture, and cut it into Trillions of Trillions of peices!!! Now drop them. What is the chance of them coming togather???

Now!!! Cut each microscopic shread into Trillions of peices each shred, and dropped them, what is the chance of them coming togather?

Now... get that to work on the first try!!!

That is how out of whack Darwinism is!!!

And the earth is much, much more complicated than that.

Study Biology, and just study a virus!!! it is soo minutly simple, yet works perfectly, and has been able to survive this long.

Random evolution is not the answer!!! Someone had to have created it in the first place.

BTW - I am not against the evolution of individual species; an evolution where dogs may have never had fur, but started to grow it during the ice age, in order to adapt. I just don't think the fact that random energy could come togather to create everything we have today.

-- NAJAWA --

title: Now for my six cents (I threw in a nickel by accident)
content:
Should ID be taught in biology classrooms, huh?

Well, the problem is that biology, and science itself, has limits. Science is the process of creating theories and hypotheses based only sight, smell, taste, touch, and sound. Something has to be 100% observable to be 100% in the realm of science.

God can not be tested for in a lab. There are mathemeticians who have deduced that God exists through high-minded stuff like quantum algebra (which I don't even begin to understand, so I'll have to take their word for it), but really, God requires faith.

So, should ID be taught in classrooms, and if so, how should it be taught?

I believe it can be taught fairly in a biology classroom. A biology teacher can point to the many steps required to construct a single cell, and just how scientifically unlikely it is for that event to happen (creating amino acids, DNA, lipids, and so on, in a nitrogen-oxygen atmosphere). The teacher could then use this highly unlikely event as scientific evidence towards the fact that, because it's so unlikely for something so ordered to be created spontaneously, a Creator was involved. Not PROOF, just evidence.

The danger comes in a biology teacher using ID to PROVE that God created the heavens and the earth. No person could do scientifically do that. In the same manner, no biology teacher could look at the evolution of the different beaks of the finches on the Galapagos islands and PROVE that humans evolved from lower primates.

ID and the Theory of Evolution are both theories about the creation of life on this planet, and they actually both agree on many key points. However, stating either of them as fact for the origin of life in a biology classroom would be unscientific.

Conclusion: Ideally, the theory that everything was created through mutation AND the theory that everything was created through a higher power - with evidence for both - should both be taught in the science classrom. But if they are taught, they should be taught very, VERY carefully.[url=http://www.screenhog.com]www.screenhog.com[/url]

title: Re: Now for my six cents (I threw in a nickel by accident)
content:
I concur.

[quote]Quote:[hr]Glovebox is right on this one. No matter how similar a process of universal or galactic evolution might be to that of plant and animal evolution, biology and astrophysics aren't identical. You can't draw conclusions about one from the other.[hr][/quote]

Scientists do, mainly cosmology is inferred from evolution rather than the other way around. For example, recent 'evolving algorithims' have benefitted from the recent postulate that evolution occurs in 'jumps' Rather than evolve slowly each program is rapidly 'mutated' like in nature, and stressed. This creates some very interesting and unexpected results. Recently a program with 'junk code' appeared; most of the junk was removable, but a small bit wasn't, yet it didn't interact at all with the rest of the code.

content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]
Should ID be taught in biology classrooms, huh?

Well, the problem is that biology, and science itself, has limits. Science is the process of creating theories and hypotheses based only sight, smell, taste, touch, and sound. Something has to be 100% observable to be 100% in the realm of science.

God can not be tested for in a lab. There are mathemeticians who have deduced that God exists through high-minded stuff like quantum algebra (which I don't even begin to understand, so I'll have to take their word for it), but really, God requires faith.

So, should ID be taught in classrooms, and if so, how should it be taught?

I believe it can be taught fairly in a biology classroom. A biology teacher can point to the many steps required to construct a single cell, and just how scientifically unlikely it is for that event to happen (creating amino acids, DNA, lipids, and so on, in a nitrogen-oxygen atmosphere). The teacher could then use this highly unlikely event as scientific evidence towards the fact that, because it's so unlikely for something so ordered to be created spontaneously, a Creator was involved. Not PROOF, just evidence.

The danger comes in a biology teacher using ID to PROVE that God created the heavens and the earth. No person could do scientifically do that. In the same manner, no biology teacher could look at the evolution of the different beaks of the finches on the Galapagos islands and PROVE that humans evolved from lower primates.

ID and the Theory of Evolution are both theories about the creation of life on this planet, and they actually both agree on many key points. However, stating either of them as fact for the origin of life in a biology classroom would be unscientific.

Conclusion: Ideally, the theory that everything was created through mutation AND the theory that everything was created through a higher power - with evidence for both - should both be taught in the science classrom. But if they are taught, they should be taught very, VERY carefully.
[hr][/quote]

Indeed. I wouldn't care if they proposed ID for a few basic ideas; however, if they started making entire chapter(s) over it, that's when I'd get pissed.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

In [I think] 1912 an italian immigrant believed he'd discovered free energy; he spun a heavy wheel so it took some time to get moving. He then stopped it moving all at once with a metal bar, which would then snap in two with great force, free energy! He managed to get this before congress. A resident physicist explained things and he left, embarassed, but admitting his error, to go on to build a flour mill.

In 1996 Mr Newman, inventor of the Newman engine did the same thing, he also had an engine that 'consumed its own wires' to give free energy. Both devices were proven fraudulent.

He claimed massive coverup, aliens, and more inventions. He now has his own company and a multimillion dollar investment fund.
